07/14/2011: Local golfer to be first American in Disabled British Open 
Clinton, N.C. — Jason Faircloth is a man with a mission 
The Clinton native, who has Cerebral Palsy, is working to found the United States Disabled Golf Association, with a goal of holding the first national-level golf championship to include golfers of all disabilities. 
“We want to inspire people,” Faircloth said. “It’s about golf, but it’s about showcasing what people can do on the golf course.” 
Faircloth’s vision is to hold a United States Disabled Open -- grouping players of all disabilities based purely on their golf skills. 
“We are trying to showcase the disabled golfers,” he said. “Not just one group, but all disabled golfers” 
Faircloth has a model in mind for this event. Similar tournaments are held in Europe and South Africa, and Faircloth himself has played in the British Disabled Open. 
“I was skeptical to even go because I never wanted people to think that I have what I have,” Faircloth said. “But when I went, it was something bigger.” 
And that’s the feeling he wants to bring to other disabled golfers here in the U.S. 
“We don’t have that level of competition,” Faircloth explained. “And that’s sad, because you’re just leaving out a lot of golfers.” 
Faircloth already has a nonprofit organization in place, but says he needs help – especially with marketing and finance -- to see his dream of a U.S. Disabled Open tee off. Credits
